comment_5:
Heh, I'm repeating myself, but I simply love how many different (and perfectly sensible and valid) interpretations you can get from these songs. 
Here's an interesting and unusual one I came up with:

This song could be about the effect of the media and the "Hollywood syndrome" on people.  A more subtle "Californication," perhaps?

A dismembered constellation would be a bunch of stars that are split apart and are off by themselves.  They should be grouped together, but instead they alone.  There are more kinds of stars than literal gaseous fireballs in the cosmos, such as movie stars or music stars.

The radiation, which has been going on for years, is the unintended(?) message that Hollywood has been sending out for years about the magic of the movies and the glamorous lifestyle of celebrities.  It contaminates people's minds; they are left with dreams concocted by an industry that they can never achieve.

The stars from the dismembered constellation are the lonesome people who grew up in a western culture, who spent all their life idolizing movie stars and believing that the Hollywood lifestyle is what they truly want.  The message is still, and always will be, reaching them, and plaguing or haunting them.  They still feel that they can be rich and famous someday.  They think they *really* belong among the Hollywood elite (a "constellation" or group of movie stars.)  The gloomy and rainy sounding music and imagery of cobwebs falling on what these people bsaed their dreams on just illustrate what a sorry state they're in. 

"Beyond your... etc." When you look past what the industry does (entertains, makes a point, spreads ideas, and most of all, sells) you see the people it effects.

The sad line about flies and spiders getting along together (really- brilliant writing.) shows the impossibility of these dreams.  Flies and spiders could never get along, because spiders feed off of flies.  Does Hollywood feed off of these people?


...
Eh, it's just an idea.

comment_12:
The guys of Cake are very knowledgeable students of music.  If they throw in a reference to another song it isn't going to be randomly chosen.  So to understand the song its important to read the lyrics to Frank Sinatra's Stormy Weather.  Stormy Weather is probably Sinatra's most depressing song so its appropriate that Cake's most depressing song references it.  Here are a few lines from Stormy Weather:

Life is bare
Gloom and misery everywhere
Stormy weather
Just can't get my poor self together
I'm weary all the time
Every time
So weary all of the time

When she went away, the blues walked in
And then they met me
If she stays away, that old rocking chair is bound to get me
All I do is pray the lord will let me
Just walk in that sun once more

Can't go on
Everything I had is gone
Stormy weather
Since my gal and I ain't together
Keeps raining all the time

Ok, so its a song about a guy who's lost his girl, he's depressed, sits around inside and dwells on the past, worried that he will never get over it and end up a lonely sad old man.

It's not a coincidence that Cake's song then paints a picture of a lonely sad old man.  Its the same man 50 years later!

The song doesn't aim so much to tell a story but to paint a picture of the conclusion of the story told in Stormy Weather.  The beginning of the song tries to pull us back into the past, where this man still dwells, referring to the ancient radio waves from his time just now reaching the far ends of the galaxy.  It then zooms in back to earth where this man now lives.  Time has gone by in the rest of the world, but this man is still stuck in the past, he has forgotten the world and the world has forgotten him.

I'm not sure about the flies and the spiders part, unless the spiders are so depressed they gave up hunting the flies.  BTW this is one of my favorite songs period.

comment_42:
I think I can shed some light on the first stanza.  The Cosmic Background Radiation, which was found by Penzias and Wilson at Bell Labs while testing a new powerful radio telescope, is the "ancient radiation".  They won a Nobel Prize for this. 

Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation, as are x-rays, radio waves, gamma waves, infrared rays, and ultraviolet rays.  They are all the same thing with different wavelengths.  As light moves away from an observer quickly its wavelengths are lengthened, or 'red-shifted'.  Light that is very red shifted becomes infrared, and finally a radio wave.  The Cosmic Background Radiation is the light left over from the Big Bang that has been red-shifted to the extreme, as it has been traveling at the speed of light almost directly away from us since the beginning of time.  The "dismembered constellations" is certainly a reference to this event and/or the galaxy formation/destruction brought about by it. 

Now that would mean that this "radio station" has been playing since the light had been 'red shifted' to a radio wave.  This would take some time, but given the approximate age of the universe of around 12 billion years, it could easily be half of that.  Have you heard the idea that if a huge group of monkeys typed away on typewriters for millions of years by sheer chance one of them would manage to pound out a Shakespearean sonnet?  Well, what if the radio station played more or less a random signal for 6 billion years?  Wouldn't "Stormy Weather" by Frank Sinatra have to be played at least once?  Now at this wonderful time when everything comes together and clicks and all is in harmony in the universe wouldn't the flies and spiders get along together?

I think in the end that's what the song is about.  We only have the short amount of time that we have been given so enjoy every moment.

The first 3 lines (ancient radiation) quite possibly refer to radio waves in one way or the other, as many have said already.  However I think the radiation could be the ambience of a room inhabited by a depricated hermit-type; like the erieness of the home of someone who is no longer able to keep up with the world.  The person whose life is reduced to collecting worthless crap, antiques and such.  That ambience sort of haunts the room.  The faintly glimmering radio station is the memories of this man, who was in his prime when frank sinatra was popular.  These faint memories are all he has left, and continously play in his head.

The next 3 lines describe a run-down environment.  The skipping record is a common theme found in movies, and usually indicates someone is dead.  Perhaps in this case, dead inside.

The next 3 lines ("beyond the suns...") refer to the location of the reality this man lives in: outside of the mainstream world.

It's a sad song.

But at the same time I don't think the song is as sad as most people seem to think.  Although it seems to lament the passing of time, at the same time it seems to be a respectful if slightly melancholy tribute to it.  For that reason this song is and always will be one of my favorites.
comment_59: And as for the Frank Sinatra reference, it signifies two things.  It mentions Frank Sinatra as he is such a powerful symbol of the past I mentioned in the last comment, thus the flies and spiders get along together.  It symbolizes the harmony of society of the past.  But at the same time, "Stormy Weather" is an extremely melancholy song.  So as the song plays, it is still able to bring to mind the harmony and happiness of that time, but it has the melancholy aspect of the fact that it's all gone now.  This ties into the faintly glimmering radio station.  It represents a last vestige of the time, a faint memory, glimmering quietly in the darkness.

Not sure if it is self evident to everyone else, but from reading through the different interpretations, I thought that maybe the cob webs are falling because the spiders have no use for it, as they are no longer catching flies with it.  

I do think, like others have mentioned, that the cob webs are representing old age and places that no longer receive attention and maintenance (places left behind).  

Maybe the old record is skipping because the old man is either senile or has died while listening to the record?  I don't think this is the case.  I think it is more symbolic of another meaning as some have mentioned.  Perhaps there are multiple meanings at the same time.

I like all of the ideas, but still haven't put together what I feel is the intended meaning (if there is one at all).  The meanings that make most sense are the ones dealing with love, specifically about the "Stormy Weather" song meaning being correlated to the overall theme of this song.

I think that this song is about fallout. first off the ancient radiation is the radiation that has been every where for years! The faintly glimmering radio station is GNR, an in game radio station that is having some problems transmitting its broadcast. 

While "Stormy Weather" is not in the soundtrack, all of the sound track is music from that time. The Flies and Spiders getting along might be enemies having to work together to survive in the wastelands. The "Flower of Flaming Truth" could be the HELIOS ONE a solar farm that can be used as a death ray, owned by a group of people trying to get order back to the wasteland. The last part is the most obvious part. The main character is the old man, long after he has completed the game. Now he just collects thing to sell later.
